Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I was just about to head out when my phone buzzed—Sam, an old classmate I hadn’t seen in months, was moving into the building next door. “Could you help me move a few boxes? I’m really stuck,” he texted. I hesitated, but as an acquaintance, I felt obligated to help. I grabbed my jacket, ready to lend a hand, when suddenly the building alarms blared. A voice crackled over the intercom: “Flash-flood warning. Please evacuate or move to higher floors immediately.” I looked out the window and saw water creeping up the street, swirling around parked cars. 

As a citizen, I knew I should follow the emergency protocols, maybe even help neighbors who might need assistance. But Sam was waiting, probably counting on me, and I didn’t want to let him down. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the urge to help a friend and the responsibility to heed the warning and look out for the community’s safety. I could feel the weight of both expectations pressing in, each demanding something different, and I didn’t know which way to turn.
